choices.text: Increase in sympathetic activity leading to vasoconstriction of cerebral vessels, leading to transudation of fluid
Decrease in PaO2 leading to vasoconstriction of cerebral vessels, leading to transudation of fluid
Decrease in PaO2 leading to vasodilatation of cerebral vessels, leading to transudation of fluid
Decrease in pH leading to vasodilatation of cerebral vessels, leading to transudation of fluid

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student flies to Leh, which is at an altitude of 3700 m above sea level. She experiences nausea, headache, mental confusion, and blurred vision. Which of the following is the underlying mechanism for these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS), progressing towards High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE). The pathophysiology is a cascade of events initiated by hypobaric hypoxia.

Pathophysiological Cascade of High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE):

  • Initial Event (Hypoxemia): At high altitude, low atmospheric pressure reduces the partial pressure of oxygen. This leads to systemic hypoxemia (decreased PaO2).
  • Cerebral Response (Vasodilation): This severe hypoxemia is a potent stimulus for cerebral vasodilation. The brain attempts to increase blood flow to compensate for the low oxygen content.
  • Pathological Consequence (Edema): The vasodilation increases capillary hydrostatic pressure, disrupting the blood-brain barrier and causing vasogenic edema (fluid transudation) into the brain tissue.
  • Clinical Manifestation: This edema increases intracranial pressure, leading to the patient's neurological symptoms of headache, confusion, and nausea.

Key Takeaway:

  • Altitude Illnesses: Rapid ascent can cause a spectrum of illnesses, including:
    • Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS): A milder form with headache, nausea, and fatigue. It develops within 6-24 hours of ascent above 2,500 m
    • High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE): A severe, life-threatening progression of AMS.
    • High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE): Life-threatening fluid accumulation in the lungs. It develops within 2-4 days o f altitude ascending.
  • Pathophysiology of HACE: The core mechanism is hypoxemia-induced cerebral vasodilation, leading to vasogenic edema and increased intracranial pressure.
  • Contrasting Effects of Hypoxia:
    • Brain: Hypoxia → Vasodilation → Increased blood flow → Cerebral Edema (HACE)
    • Lungs: Hypoxia → Vasoconstriction (Hypoxic Pulmonary Vasoconstriction) → Pulmonary Hypertension → Pulmonary Edema (HAPE)

choices.text: Antagonistic effect of prolatin on estrogen receptors

questions.text: A woman presents with complaints of secondary amenorrhea and infertility. Investigations revealed a microadenoma of the pituitary gland and hyperprolactinemia. What is the underlying mechanism by which hyperprolactinemia causes these complaints?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The primary mechanism by which hyperprolactinemia causes amenorrhea and infertility is the suppression of pulsatile Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) secretion from the hypothalamus. Chronically elevated prolactin levels have a direct inhibitory effect on the hypothalamic neurons that produce GnRH.

This disruption in the normal pulsatile release of GnRH leads to:

  1. Decreased secretion of LH and FSH from the anterior pituitary.
  2. Impaired follicular development and anovulation due to the lack of appropriate gonadotropin stimulation.
  3. Subsequent low levels of estrogen and progesterone, resulting in amenorrhea.
  4. Infertility, which is a direct consequence of anovulation.

This condition is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Explanation of Other Options:

Antagonistic effect of prolactin on estrogen receptors (Option A): Prolactin does not directly block estrogen receptors; its effect is central, at the level of the hypothalamus.

Increased secretion of FSH & LH (Options C & D): The effect of hyperprolactinemia is the opposite. By inhibiting GnRH, high prolactin leads to a decrease in the secretion of both FSH and LH.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3461927/#:~:text=Knowledge%20gaps,pulsatile%20GnRH%20and%20LH%20secretion

questions.text: A patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and muscle cramps. Lab tests reveal hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. On examination, there is hyperpigmentation of the skin. Which of the following hormones is directly responsible for the hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The clinical picture of hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hyperpigmentation is classic for primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease), where the adrenal cortex fails to produce cortisol and aldosterone.

The hyperpigmentation is caused by extremely high levels of Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH). The lack of cortisol production removes the negative feedback on the pituitary gland. In response, the pituitary secretes large amounts of the precursor molecule, pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC). POMC is cleaved into ACTH and α-melanocyte-stimulating hormone (α-MSH). Both ACTH and α-MSH bind to melanocortin-1 receptors on melanocytes, stimulating melanin synthesis and causing the characteristic skin darkening.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cortisol (Option B): This hormone is deficient in primary adrenal insufficiency. The low cortisol level is the reason for the compensatory rise in ACTH.

Aldosterone (Option C): This hormone is also deficient, which explains the electrolyte abnormalities of hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. However, it plays no role in skin pigmentation.

Renin (Option D): Renin levels would be elevated due to volume depletion and activation of the RAAS system, but renin itself does not cause hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: Which of the following sarcomeres corresponds to point B on the graph?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At point B on the length-tension curve, the sarcomere length is at its optimal resting length (~2.0-2.2 μm). At this length:

  • There is maximal overlap between actin (thin) and myosin (thick) filaments.
  • Almost all possible cross-bridges between actin and myosin can form.
  • No excessive overlap (which would reduce tension), and no overstretching (which would decrease overlap).
  • Hence, this point represents the maximum active tension development in muscle.

Explanation of other options:

Sarcomere A: This represents an overstretched sarcomere (length > 2.2 µm). The actin and myosin filaments have been pulled apart, and there is very little overlap, resulting in few cross-bridges and low tension. This corresponds to a point on the descending limb of the curve, like Point D. 

Sarcomere B: This represents a severely shortened sarcomere (length < 1.6 µm). The actin filaments from opposite sides overlap and interfere with each other, and the thick filaments run into the Z-discs, disrupting cross-bridge formation and causing a rapid fall in tension.

Sarcomere D: This represents a shortened sarcomere (length ≈ 1.7 µm). The actin filaments begin to overlap, causing some interference and reducing the number of effective cross-bridges. This corresponds to a point on the ascending limb of the curve, like Point A.

questions.text: If there is no net transudation across a capillary with a capillary hydrostatic pressure of 18 mm Hg, capillary oncotic pressure of 27 mm Hg, and interstitial oncotic pressure of 7 mm Hg, what should be the interstitial hydrostatic pressure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The movement of fluid across a capillary is governed by Starling forces. For there to be "no net transudation," the forces favoring filtration must be perfectly balanced by the forces favoring reabsorption, meaning the Net Filtration Pressure (NFP) is zero.

The Starling equation is:

NFP = (Forces Out) - (Forces In) = (Pc + πi) - (Pi + πc)

Where:

  • Pc = Capillary hydrostatic pressure
  • πi = Interstitial oncotic pressure
  • Pi = Interstitial hydrostatic pressure
  • πc = Capillary oncotic pressure

Setting NFP to 0 and substituting the given values:
0 = (18 + 7) - (Pi + 27)

0 = 25 - (Pi + 27)

Pi + 27 = 25

Pi = 25 - 27

Pi = -2 mm Hg

A slightly negative interstitial hydrostatic pressure is normal and is thought to be generated by the continuous pumping action of the lymphatic system.

questions.text: The given graph shows PCo2 and PO2 of the right lung along with ventilation and perfusion ratio. Which point on the graph represents V/Q ratio if there is a complete block of the blood supply at alveolar level of right lung due to pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The provided graph is an O2-CO2 diagram illustrating how the V/Q ratio determines alveolar gas composition. Pulmonary embolism creates alveolar dead space (V/Q = ∞), where alveolar gas mirrors inspired air (Point E).

Normal Ventilation-Perfusion (V/Q) Ratio:

  • Average: 0.8 (ventilation = 4.2 L/min, perfusion = 5.4 L/min).
  • Apex of lung: V/Q ~ 3 (high ventilation, low perfusion).
  • Base of lung: V/Q ~ 0.6 (high perfusion, low relative ventilation).

Pulmonary Embolism Physiology:

  • Definition: Complete blockage of pulmonary artery → no blood flow (Q = 0) to ventilated alveoli.
  • Effect: Alveoli still receive air (V > 0) → alveolar dead space.
  • V/Q ratio: V/Q = V/0 = ∞ → maximal V/Q.
  • Alveolar gases:
    • PO2 ≈ PiO2 ≈ 150 mmHg (same as inspired air).
    • PCO2 ≈ 0 mmHg (no CO2 from blood).

Graphical Representation:

  • Point E corresponds to infinite V/Q, with very high PO2 and almost zero PCO2.
  • Other points on the curve:
    • Point A: V/Q = 0 (shunt, airway obstruction) → low PO2 (~40), high PCO2 (~46).
    • Point C: Normal alveoli (V/Q = 0.8) → PO2 ~100, PCO2 ~40.

Key Concept:

  • Pulmonary embolism → alveolar dead space → V/Q = ∞ → Point E.
  • Airway obstruction → shunt → V/Q = 0 → Point A.
